title: Consumer Companies Must Innovate to Drive Impact on Climate - BCG
summary: The article discusses the challenges and opportunities in the Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG) sector regarding sustainability and innovation. It emphasizes consumers' growing climate concerns and the necessity for CPG companies to adapt their products and business processes for sustainability. Companies like Nestlé and AB InBev are highlighted as leaders in leveraging innovation to address environmental impacts, focusing on transforming their product offerings and supply chains through sustainable practices. The article suggests that activating consumer behavior and deploying advanced digital tools are essential steps for CPG companies to enhance their sustainability efforts.

title: Fact-or-Myth: Bio-based, organic, biodegradable - Cordis News
summary: The article clarifies misconceptions about bio-based and organic products, stating they are not the same; bio-based refers to materials derived from living organisms, while organic relates to sustainable agricultural practices. It addresses myths about the environmental friendliness of bio-based products, suggesting they are not automatically more sustainable or biodegradable. Additionally, it distinguishes between biodegradability and compostability, noting that while all compostable items are biodegradable, not all biodegradable items are compostable, as composting requires specific conditions. The text emphasizes the need for clear definitions and context around these terms.

title: Exxon’s new ‘advanced recycling’ plant raises environmental concerns - The Guardian US
summary: ExxonMobil has launched one of the largest chemical recycling plants in North America aimed at recycling hard-to-recycle plastics. However, environmental advocates argue that the facility may generate hazardous pollutants and serves as a distraction from reducing overall plastic production. The pyrolysis method employed by the plant has been criticized for being more environmentally damaging than mechanical recycling and traditional plastic production. Critics claim that instead of addressing the plastic crisis, the company is using this technology to justify continued plastic production.
green_innovation: FALSE, because the process described deploys harmful methods that produce pollution and environmental damage while failing to address the root issue of plastic waste.
business_innovation: TRUE, as the launch of the chemical recycling plant represents a new business process that significantly alters ExxonMobil's operations regarding plastic recycling.
green_product: FALSE, because the products generated through this recycling process are not designed with a significantly lower environmental impact throughout their lifecycle.
green_process: FALSE, because the process of pyrolysis described does not effectively minimize environmental impacts and instead may worsen pollution and energy consumption.

title: IGI Wins $70 Million to Study Microbiome Engineering for Health, Climate Challenges - Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News
summary: A research initiative co-led by Nobel laureate Jennifer Doudna aims to combine genome editing with microbiome research to address climate and health challenges, funded by a $70 million grant. The project intends to use CRISPR technology for precision editing of microbiomes to treat diseases and reduce greenhouse gas emissions while collaborating with several UC campuses. Researchers plan to study the effects of gut microbiota on childhood asthma and evaluate dietary interventions in livestock to mitigate methane emissions. The initiative aims to share findings globally, focusing on accessible solutions for low- and middle-income farmers.

title: California approves phase-out of large diesel-powered trucks - Vijesti.me
summary: California has approved a rule banning the sale of new diesel-powered tow trucks and buses starting in 2036 to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and pollution from heavy-duty vehicles.
